ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
ADULT EDUCATION TV PRODUCTION AND TRAINING
CENTRE PROJECT (CEPTA TV)
(Functions and financial commitments)


    1. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Culture what percentage of the total expenses of the Adult Education TV Production and Training Centre Project does his Ministry's share represent; what kind of programmes will be produced, for what audience and where; and what kind of personnel will be trained.

Column: 1222



    The Minister for Culture (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not possible at this initial stage to say precisely what percentage of the total expenses of the Adult Education TV Production and Training Centre Project (known as CEPTA TV) my Ministry's share represents. This is because the project will take three to four years before it becomes fully operational.

    However, an idea can be gauged from its financial commitment which is as follows :

    (i) Government will provide suitable building accommodation for CEPTA TV to house offices, equipment, service and other technical areas. The building is estimated to cost in the region of $1 million;

Column: 1223



    (ii) Government will also provide 50 per cent of the annually recurrent operating costs of CEPTA TV, subject to a maximum of $900,000 per year;

    (iii) The Friedrich Ebert Stiftung of the Federal Republic of Germany will supply equipment and supporting facilities estimated at $6.5 million for CEPTA TV's operation;

    (iv) The Stiftung will also pay 50 per cent of the annually recurrent operating costs of CEPTA TV up to $900,000, plus anything in excess of the joint limit of $1.8 million. The amount of $500,000 provided under Head 51, subhead 103, of the 1972-73 Development Estimates is intended to meet the capital expenditure on the first stage of the building construction.

    CEPTA TV's activities will be carried out on a regional basis and the Centre will produce adult education programmes which will provide useful audio-visual support for national institutions in Asia engaged in the promotion of adult education through television and other audio-visual means. The programmes will be produced in Singapore, for use not only in Singapore, but also in other countries in Asia which participate in the project. The audiences, therefore, will be in Singapore and in the Asian countries that participate.

    The personnel who will be trained include television programmers, engineers, and other personnel in the adult education field. The training of personnel in specific areas of television production will be carried Out in conjunction with the Centre's programme production activities. Much of the training will be given on an on-the-job basis.

    Tuan Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 78 be reduced by $10 in respect of item 001 of subhead 101*.

    (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Ng Kah Ting.)

    Sir, I have said in this Parliament a week ago that all the roads in the eastern sector have been made up under the Local Government Integration Act, except the roads in Kampong Pachitan, Lengkong Tiga and Kampong Eunos. Kampong Pachitan is private property, and the land is let out to the residents who are now occupying it. The roads there are mainly earth roads. When it rains, they become impassable because the mud turns soggy. Therefore, I would like to request the Minister concerned to make up the roads to kampong standard.

    Kampong Eunos is a reserve road. A community centre has been built by the residents themselves at the cost of $110,000, and it is operational. But because the existing roads are not constructed in accordance with the road reserve, therefore, Sir, I hope the authorities concerned can make up Kampong Eunos road under section 19 of the Local Government Integration Act. Otherwise the authorities have to divert the existing Kampong Eunos road, in accordance with the reserve road, so that the centre area can be extended and development work there can be carried out early.

    Mr Speaker, I refer to the kampong roads in Alsagoff Estate in Kampong Kembangan constituency. Only certain roads in that estate have been made up to kampong standards. A greater number has yet to be made up, and up to now they are still nothing but earth roads. So when it rains, the drain becomes clogged and overflows on to the roads, making the roads muddy. Sir, I would like to know why these roads have not been made up when

applications have already been submitted to the Urban and Rural Services Committee many years ago, and when can they be made up according to kampong standards?

    Sir, applications for roads to be built have not been considered and applications to fill up pot-holes in the roads have not been entertained. It is strange but true, Sir, that although applications have been made to the U.R.S.C, to repair Jalan Ladang, including roadside drains, the sum approved to repair the road is up to a limit of $700 only. Despite the fact that repair work has commenced, the badly damaged roads have not been repaired. Instead the other roads which only require minor repairs have been attended to. I wish to know how this state of affairs can be allowed to go on, and whether applications to metal roads in Alsagoff Estate, Kampong Ubi and Kampong Kembangan constituencies can be approved this year.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, may I first congratulate the Urban and Rural Services Committee, headed by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development, for providing various amenities in the rural areas, such as making up of kampong roads, water and electricity supplies, street lighting, etc.

    It is noted that the apportionment of this fund for the various constituencies varies considerably. Though much has been done in this respect, for which my constituents and I are indeed grateful, Sir, there is, however, still plenty of room for improvement. For example, in the Trafalgar Estate, which formerly housed the Trafalgar Receiving Station, there are a few hundred families, most of whom are farmers. There is no water supply there, though electricity supplies are available presently. Also in Track 6, off Punggol Road, the residents have requested for water supplies for a long time. I hope the Minister concerned, or his Parliamentary Secretary, will favourably consider my requests in this respect. There are other requests too, for example, electricity supplies, but I would not like to bother this House with details except to say that I hope such requests can be acceded to as soon as possible.

    Sir, I understand that the Public Utilities Board has been implementing rural electrification schemes costing about $2.65 million per annum. I wonder whether the Parliamentary Secretary is actually taking steps to expedite the implementation of such schemes. I say this because now and again we receive progress reports of such schemes being carried out, and it is noticed that in some of my areas implementation will not be carried out until a year or two later.

    Sir, another aspect that I wish to bring to the attention of the Minister concerned is street lighting in the rural areas. First of all, most of the street lights that have been put up are not bright enough, probably due to low

wattage, and they get out of order every now and then. In this respect, I would urge the Minister concerned to look into the possibility of installing brighter and more durable lights.

2.45 p.m.

    Sir, another aspect I would like to touch on is the state of agricultural and kampong roads. Many agricultural and kampong roads have been constructed in the past few years, but I am afraid that by now most of them are in urgent need of repair. Therefore, may I once again request the Minister concerned to look into this matter. It is gratifying to note that this year's provision is $3.25 million. It shows a marked increase over last year's provision. I hope that the Urban and Rural Services Committee would be generous enough to entertain the requests of the rural constituencies.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether or not it is proper for me to raise one question. It is near the Gan Eng Seng School. The children going to and from the school do not use this overhead bridge because they have to cross two other roads where there is more traffic, before they can come to this overhead bridge. But there are no overhead bridges for these two other roads where the traffic is very heavy. Therefore, the school children do not wish to utilise the overhead bridge near their school. I do not know whether or not the other Members of Parliament were consulted when an overhead bridge was built in their constituencies. But in this case, neither my Citizens' Consultative Committee nor myself was consulted. Last Sunday I drove through my constituency -

    Sir, I am in full agreement with what the Member for Punggol has said. The provision for rural services is $3.25 million, and although this is more than last year's provision, it is still not sufficient. If this provision were to be distributed to the various constituencies, each constituency will only get $10,000 or less. This amount Xs not even enough to metal a road. I think a provision of two or three times more than the present provision of $3.25 million should he allocated. Since we are making rapid progress in our economic development, more provision should be made so that the living conditions of the people in the rural areas can be improved.

Column: 1229



    Mr Speaker, Sir, as a matter of fact, the requests made by the people in the rural areas are basically very simple. They want roads properly surfaced, drains to flow smoothly, and public utility services like water, electricity and street lighting. Water is their most urgent need. In the last few years the Government has extended the water mains to the various constituencies. However, there are many areas, especially in the more remote parts, which still do not have water supply. In these areas, the people have to dig wells for their water. Whether or not these wells are hygienic is another matter. In any case, during the dry spells the wells will dry up and they have to depend on Government delivery trucks which give only a limited supply of water. This is a great inconvenience to them. I know that many constituencies have requested for water supplies but their applications have not been approved. The authorities concerned have replied that it is uneconomic to extend the water mains to these remote areas. I hope they will not be too calculating in the analysis of cost and profit. I hope the people in these more remote areas will be provided with adequate water supplies.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the people in the rural areas also want better roads. They would like to see all the present mud tracks properly metalled with tar. These mud tracks, which are used by the villagers every day, are uneven, and they hold many puddles of water. This is a great inconvenience to the villagers. The mud tracks in the villages can only last for a short time. In the case of laterite tracks, after a year or two of use, there will be many pot-holes which have to be repaired. During the dry season, the laterite tracks become very dusty, and when it rains they are very muddy. This has caused a lot of hardship especially to the primary school children, because their clean white shoes become dirty with red mud after walking on these laterite tracks. Moreover, these laterite tracks are not durable. Every two or three years they have to be repaired.

Column: 1230

The repair will cost a few thousand dollars. Mr Speaker, Sir, I know that it is impossible to metal all the tracks within six months or even a year. But I would like to see a greater provision made so that more laterite roads will be metalled. However, I hope that the provision of more metalled roads will not mean a deterioration in the quality of the roads. In my constituency, I notice that there are many metalled roads with a lot of pot-holes. As soon as one part of a road is repaired, potholes appear in another part. In less than two years the road seems like an old shirt with mendings everywhere. What is surprising to me is that some of these roads have pot-holes in less than six months after their construction. I have taken photographs showing the terrible condition of these roads, and I have shown them to the Parliamentary Secretary. I am not an engineer and, therefore, I am not familiar with the technical points involved in road construction. But the fact that these roads are easily damaged shows that the foundation of the road is not strong. Why cannot the relevant department first assess the maximum weight the road can support and then make the foundation accordingly. If this is not done, as soon as a road is constructed, repairs have to be carried out every now and again. This will be a waste of public funds. Moreover, some of these pot-holes are not mended in time. I hope the Parliamentary Secretary will look into this matter and provide better roads for the people in the rural areas.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, people in the rural areas also want the drains to flow smoothly. When the drains are clogged up, they are not only a breeding ground for mosquitoes, but they also give out a terrible stench. This is very unhygienic. Moreover, excessive water from the silted drain will erode the surface of the road. I hope the department concerned will organise teams of workmen to clear the major drains in every rural constituency at least once a year.

Column: 1231



    The people in the rural areas also require electricity supply. The Public Utilities Board has said that it will provide rural electrification within one or two years. I hope the Board will keep its word. The people in the rural constituencies also want street lighting. Street lighting will make the road users feel much safer and thus more conducive to the maintenance of law and order. I hope all the rural areas will be provided with street lighting.

    Although there are not many rural constituencies in Singapore, their total areas are quite big. We do need a greater provision for rural services. I hope that in the next Budget the Parliamentary Secretary will request a bigger provision from the Minister for Finance for the development of these rural areas.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I fully agree with my colleagues who have spoken on rural services. They are representatives of the people from the rural areas. This year a provision of $3.25 million is made for urban and rural services, and I appreciate that the Government has made a bigger provision than for last year. However, I agree with the Member for Jurong when he said that this increased provision is still not sufficient for many of the projects in the rural areas. For example, there is a very urgent need to provide for more rural roads. Although many applications have been made, not many roads have been constructed. The excuse given is that there is not enough provision. This shows that more provision is needed for the construction of roads in the rural areas.

    I would like to raise two points. First, the provision for the construction of roads is only $750,000. It seems to me that this sum is too small. There are many roads in my constituency which are yet to be constructed. Of course, there are also other areas like Jurong, Punggol and Chua Chu Kang (which is the constituency of the Minister of State for Finance), Nee

Column: 1232

Soon, Changi, Bukit Panjang, Jalan Kayu, etc. If we were to distribute the provision among these various constituencies, then the sum for each constituency will be very small and it will not be sufficient. Since we have a surplus budget this year, I think we can well afford to provide a few million dollars more for rural development. So I would ask the Minister concerned to consider increasing this provision.

3.00 p.m.

    The second point relates to the supply of water, which is a very important matter. In the past, we had many public standpipes. But the Government has been encouraging people to install their own water-pipes and there has been a decrease in the number of public standpipes. The provision of $1.5 million for the extension of water supply is insufficient and I hope that the Minister will consider increasing this amount. During a dry spell, perhaps the Minister of State for Finance may remember, the Government had to arrange for water wagons and lorries to supply water to the people in Chua Chu Kang and other rural constituencies. But in Sembawang, we are lucky because we can dig wells and the area is not too dry. So we are more fortunate. I hope the Minister will consider increasing the provision for the extension of water supply.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Mr Speaker. Sir, last year, under this subhead. I raised the question of insufficiency of funds allocated to the Urban and Rural Services Committee for making up agricultural and kampong roads. For 1972-73, there is an increase of $300,000, and I would like to thank the Minister for Law and National Development for giving full consideration to our plea.

    For the next financial year the provision for item 013 - Jetties - has been reduced by $25,000. I believe that this meagre sum of $50,000 is for the repair of jetties in the Southern Islands - Pulau Ubin. Pulau Tekong - and also other jetties on our main island.

Sir, Members representing the constituencies such as Jurong, Telok Blangah and Pasir Panjang have got surrounding islands to look after. Therefore, I think you will agree with me that $50,000 will not be enough to repair the very bad condition of the jetty at Pulau Ubin. Sir, this year, I would like to plead again with the Minister to consider increasing the provision for this item.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the various Parliament representatives of the rural constituencies in regard to the provision of rural services. I have two questions to raise with the Minister. The first question relates to drains in rural constituencies. Up to this moment, I think there is no comprehensive plan to construct a good drainage system. In our Budget for 1972-73, there is no provision for the construction of drains. I would like to know whether Government is going to provide a special scheme for the construction of drains in the rural areas.

    The second question relates to the supply of electricity. In the last few years, the authorities concerned have done very well in this respect. Not only have they spent their own time visiting the rural areas, but they have also contacted the various Members of Parliament in order to do a better job, and I would like to thank the authorities concerned on this matter. But some Members just now mentioned that there are schemes for rural electrification which have not yet been carried out. I think this is not a question of inefficiency. It is more a question of getting enough contractors to carry out the projects so that the electrification of the rural areas could be carried out more efficiently.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon): Mr Speaker, Sir, in reply to the Member

Column: 1234

for Kampong Kembangan regarding Kampong Eunos, there is no plan at the moment to make up the stretch of road from Kampong Eunos to Jalan Yasin, as the area is heavily squattered. Improvement to the existing track may be considered if a request is made to the Urban and Rural Services Committee by the Citizens' Consultative Committee.

    As regards Alsagoff Estate, in fact, we have carried out quite a lot of improvements in the Kampong Kembangan, Kampong Ubi and Geylang Serai areas. For instance, we have extended Sims Avenue to Jalan Eunos, and constructed the Pan-Island Expressway from Paya Lebar Road to Jalan Eunos. We have also widened and improved Jalan Ubi and Jalan Eunos. With the two new major roads and the other two improved roads just mentioned, the improvement in the street lighting, drainage and foot-paths have contributed considerably to the convenience of the people living in the area. As Alsagoff Estate will eventually become a housing and industrial estate, it is unwise at this stage to make up all the side tracks in the area as this will in course of time be broken up, and it will be a waste of public funds. However, if it is necessary to carry out minor repairs, we will always meet the requests when they are received from time to time.

    The Public Works Department has no immediate plans to make up the portion of Jalan Ubi from Jalan Lada to Airport Road, as this would be affected by Housing Board development of this area which is still in the planning stage.

    In reply to the Member for Punggol, the Public Utilities Board has taken action to improve the servicing of street lamps in public and kampong roads, and the quality of lamps used will also be improved.

    Sir, in Punggol, three water-main laying schemes for the Trafalgar Estate in Punggol have been approved recently, and work will commence within the

Column: 1235

next three months. They are as follows:

    (1) Lorong Renjong from Lorong Buang Kok to Trafalgar Estate. The cost is $21,000.

    (2) Tracks in Trafalgar Estate. The cost is $55,000.

    (3) Tracks adjoining Trafalgar Estate. The cost is $12,500. The total cost will be $88,500.

    Another scheme for Track 6, Punggol Road, and many more water-main laying schemes for Punggol and for areas in other constituencies have been approved recently and work will be carried out soon.

    Regarding the rural electrification schemes, Sir, this provision of $50,000 is for the supply of electricity by generators to the off-shore islands, which cannot be reached by the Public Utilities Board's supply. Electrification schemes for the mainland are met from P.U.B, funds. For this year, the provision is $2.6 million. It was unfortunate that the Electricity Department of the P.U.B., due to factors beyond their control, could not implement approved electrification schemes within the time specified in the programme. For example, last year, owing to the floods in Calcutta, the factories under contract were unable to supply overhead materials. The floods in Malaysia also resulted in a shortage of wooden poles. Nevertheless, even with these setbacks, the P.U.B, carried out and completed 35 rural electrification schemes between April, 1971, and 22nd March, 1972, benefiting about 2,000 houses at a cost of $660,000 while 23 other schemes as at 22nd March, 1972, benefiting about 3,000 more houses and costing $1 million, are still in progress.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, both the Members for Jurong and Sembawang have asked for more money to be provided for the repair of agricultural and kampong roads. In fact, Jurong constituency, for instance, was allocated $77,000 for 1971-72, but $88,000 was committed. So for Jurong constituency, the provision was over-committed by $11,000. The

Column: 1236

provision for Sembawang constituency was $15,000, but $66,000 was committed. Similarly, Sembawang constituency was over-committed by $51,000. Sir, from a comparison of these figures, we have, in fact, spent more money in the rural constituencies. For 1972-73, the provision for roads and other services has been increased by one-third over the previous year's provision. Whether or not more funds will be provided in the coming years will depend on the number of requests for services and the amounts involved. However, the Members from the rural constituencies can be assured that if there is a balance of funds uncommitted in the other constituencies, it will ultimately be utilised for the rural constituencies.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the last 11 years about $10 million out of a total expenditure of $37 million was spent on improvement of roads in the rural constituencies. Most of these roads have considerably improved. The Government has the immediate task of extending piped-water supplies to households in the rural areas. In the next few years we will step up the laying of water-mains in areas where the people are still dependent on well-water. In areas where the people are dependent on public standpipes, these standpipes will be removed when water-mains are laid. The areas which need water-mains are Bukit Panjang, Bukit Timah, Changi, Chua Chu Kang, Jalan Kayu, Jurong, Kampong Chai Chee, Nee Soon, Punggol, Tampines, and, of course, Sembawang. It is hoped that with the stepping up of this scheme, every household in the outlying areas would, in the next three or four years, be able to enjoy piped-water facilities.

    In reply to the Member for Changi, there is no proposal for the construction of new jetties. The provision of $50,000 for this year should be sufficient for the maintenance of existing jetties. However, if there is a need to construct new jetties, the U.R.S.C, will make a request to the Finance Ministry for more funds.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Parliamentary Secretary for doing his part in looking after the people in the rural areas.
